labour</topcClas>         <topcClas>General - Health</topcClas>         <topcClas>Health services and medical care - Health</topcClas>         <topcClas>Housing</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social indicators and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Use and provision of specific social services - Social welfare policy and systems</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <I>Continuous Household Survey</I> (CHS) is one of the largest continuous surveys carried out in Northern Ireland.  The survey is designed, conducted and analysed by the Central Survey Unit of the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA).  It is based on a sample of the general population resident in private households and has been running since 1983.  The Survey is designed to provide a regular source of information on a wide range of social and economic issues relevant to Northern Ireland.  The CHS is an important source of information in Northern Ireland and is used by many Government departments and Agencies.  Regular clients include the Departments of Enterprise, Trade and Investment, Culture Arts and Leisure, Regional Developments, Environment, Education, Employment and Learning and NISRA. <br> <br> Further information about the series, including methodology, may be found on the NISRA Central Survey Unit (CSU) <a href="http://www.csu.nisra.gov.uk/survey.asp2.htm" title="CSU Surveys: CHS">Continuous Household Survey</a> web pages.<br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The main subject coverage of the data includes household and individual demographics, housing characteristics, changing population trends, household internet access, car access, household attitudes and behaviour towards environmental issues, individual participation in sports, arts and culture activities, individual usage of the internet, educational attainment, employment and health.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2012-04-01T00:00:00Z">April 2012</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2013-03-01T00:00:00Z">March 2013</collDate>         <nation>Northern Ireland</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Households</universe>         <universe>Private households in Northern Ireland.</universe>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Data are collected annually</timeMeth>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>The CHS is based on a systematic random sample of addresses drawn each year from the Land and Property Services Agency's (LPSA) list of domestic addresses. The LPSA addresses are sorted by district council and ward, so the sample is effectively stratified geographically. Data is collected by personal interview using CAPI, and the interviews are spread equally over the 12 months from April to March.</sampProc>         <deviat>The Household data is based on the responses of 2,712 households.  The individual data is based on the responses of 3,625 individuals.  Record 15 contains the details of 2,888 family units living in the 2,712 households.</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>A chi square goodness-of-fit test showed that the CHS achieved individual sample in 2012-13 was not representative of the population by age and sex when compared with mid-year population estimates. As a result, three separate weights have been produced for analysing by age, sex and age and sex combined and these are available for all the individual records (Records 3-14).</weight>         <cleanOps>A*</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.</restrctn>         <contact><a
